definitions.definition: Senses relating to exerting force or pulling .

subdefinitions.definition: To pull (someone or something) in a particular direction or manner .
examples: He drew a sheaf of papers from his bag.

subdefinitions.definition: To move (a body part ) in a particular direction.
examples: She settled in the window seat, drawing her leg up beneath her.

subdefinitions.definition: Often followed by tight : to pull (something, such as a belt or string ) so that it tightens or wraps around something more closely .
examples: She took a deep breath and drew her corset-strings.

subdefinitions.definition: To drag (something), especially along the ground .
To pull ( blinds , a curtain , etc.) open or closed .
examples: She drew the curtains to let in the sunlight.
You should draw the curtains at night for privacy.

subdefinitions.definition: To pull out (a bolt or latch ) to unlock a door , gate , etc.; also, to push in (a bolt or latch) to lock a door, gate, etc.
Chiefly followed by aside or to one side : to move (someone) away from a group of people in order to speak to them privately .
To assume a specific attitude or position , either by pulling in or stretching out one's body or limbs .
examples: He drew himself to his full height and glowered at the interloper.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (a body part) to contract or shrink ; also, to pull (the mouth , the face or features , etc.) out of shape from emotion , etc.; to distort . [from 14th c.] ( archaic ) To cause (someone or something) to go from one place to another, or from one condition to another. ( archaic ) To construct (a canal , wall , etc.) from one point to another. [from 15th c.] ( billiards ) To strike (the cue ball ) below the centre so as to give it a backward rotation which causes it to move backwards on striking another ball . [from 19th c.] ( bowls ) To cause (a bowl ) to move in a curve to a certain place. ( cricket , archaic ) Of a batter : to hit (a ball) from the off side to the leg side , especially with an inclined bat ; also, to hit (a short - length ball directed at the leg stump ) with an inclined bat so as to deflect the ball between the legs and the wicket . [from 19th c.] ( curling ) To play (a shot or a stone ) that lands in the house ( “ circular target ” ) . [from 18th c.] ( golf ) To hit (the ball) with the toe of the club so that it is deflected toward the left (or, for a left-handed player , toward the right , originally in an uncontrolled and now a controlled manner. [from 19th c.] ( nautical ) Of a vessel : to require (a certain depth of water ) to float in.
examples: This ship draws ten feet of water.

subdefinitions.definition: To drag (someone) by tying behind a horse or on a frame as a form of punishment or torture , or to bring to a place of execution . To kill someone as a form of punishment or torture by tearing apart (their body) by tying their limbs to horses which run in different directions; also, to tear (the limbs) from someone's body in this manner.
To pull back (an arrow or bowstring ) in preparation for shooting the arrow; also, to cause (a bow ) to bend by pulling back the bowstring.
To subject (a number ) to an arithmetic operation .
to haul in (a fishing net ) which has been cast ; also, to drag (a fishing net) alongside a boat .
To hoist (a sail ).
To carry (a load ) in a vehicle; to cart , to haul.

To sew together (the edges of a tear ); also, to mend (a hole or tear) in fabric . To use (a draught animal) to pull a plough or vehicle. ( figurative ) To attribute (something) to a person or thing; to ascribe . ( figurative ) To change (something) into another thing; to convert , to transform . ( figurative ) To convert (a passage ) from one literary style to another (for example, from prose to verse ); or to translate (a text) from one language to another. ( figurative ) To direct (one's heart , thoughts , etc.) in a certain way or towards someone or something. ( figurative ) To give ( courage , strength , etc.) to oneself; to summon up ; also, to produce ( evil , wickedness , etc.) in oneself. ( figurative ) To give (words) a certain meaning , especially one which is distorted ; to distort , to misrepresent . ( figurative , cooking ) Followed by through : to pass ( food ) through a strainer . ( figurative , cooking ) To mix (an ingredient ) with another ingredient or ingredients to form a liquid or paste ; to mix (ingredients) together to form a liquid or paste.
To be ( able to be) pulled in a particular direction or manner.
Of blinds , a curtain , etc.: to be pulled open or closed .

Of a bowl: to move in a curve to a certain place. ( curling ) To make a shot that lands in the house. ( nautical ) Followed by an adverb , such as deep or shallow : of a vessel : to require a depth of water of a certain characteristic to float in.

Especially of a draught animal : to pull something, such as a plough or vehicle , along; to have force to move something by pulling. [from 14th c.] Of a plough or vehicle: to be pulled along in a specified manner. [from 19th c.] To become contracted ; to shrink .
examples: This horse draws well.
The carriage draws easily.

subdefinitions.definition: To pull back an arrow or bowstring in preparation for shooting the arrow; also, to cause a bow to bend by pulling back the bowstring.
To work together towards a common aim ; to cooperate , to pull together ; also, to have a good relationship with; to get on with .
To be dragged along; to drag. To pull at something; to tug .
To induce (the attention , the eyes or mind , etc.) to be directed at or focused on something.
examples: From the moment she entered the room, all eyes were drawn to her.
His mind was drawn back to the events of the preceding morning.

subdefinitions.definition: To attract or cause (someone) to come to a particular place or to take a particular course of action ; also, to cause (someone) to turn away from a particular condition or course of action.
To attract (something) by means of a physical force , especially gravity or magnetism .
To attract or provoke (a particular reaction or response ) from someone.
examples: The president’s comments have drawn strong criticism from right-wing media outlets.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (something) to occur as a consequence ; to bring about .
Followed by on or upon : to bring ( disaster or misfortune ) on oneself.
To receive (a particular prison sentence ).
To take ( air , smoke , etc.) into the lungs ; to breathe in , to inhale .
examples: I drew a deep breath and wiped my brow.

subdefinitions.definition: To cause (air) to be sucked into a duct , a room , etc.
To drag or suck deeply on (a cigarette , pipe , or other smoking implement ).
To attract or provoke gunfire , either intentionally or unintentionally .
To attract or influence a person or group of people; to be an inducement or enticement .
To take a drink of a beverage , especially an alcoholic one; to swig .
Of a duct, smoking implement, etc.: to allow air to be passed through it in order that combustion can occur.
examples: The chimney won’t draw properly if it’s clogged up with soot.

subdefinitions.definition: Followed by at or on : to drag or suck deeply on a cigarette, pipe, or other smoking implement.
Chiefly followed by about or around : of a group of people: to come together ; to assemble , to congregate , to gather .

definitions.definition: Senses relating to extending or protracting .

subdefinitions.definition: To make (something) larger or longer ; to elongate , to stretch.
examples: The dough was run through the pasta machine and drawn into a long ribbon.

subdefinitions.definition: Followed by out : to flatten (a piece of metal ), usually by hammering .
To make ( wire ) by pulling a rod or other piece of metal through one or more apertures ; also, to stretch (a rod or other piece of metal) into a wire.
examples: to draw a mass of metal into wire

subdefinitions.definition: To make ( straw straight for thatching by pulling it through the hands .
To amount to (a certain quantity or sum ). To extend the duration of (something); to prolong . [10th–19th c.] To stretch (someone) on a rack as a form of punishment or torture.
To be made larger or longer; to be elongated or stretched.
To make straw straight for thatching by pulling it through the hands.
Of a sail: to fill with wind and become taut .
examples: The ship’s sail drew when the wind blew strongly.

subdefinitions.definition: To amount to a certain quantity or sum. To extend in area or space ; to spread , to stretch.

definitions.definition: Senses relating to extracting or selecting .

subdefinitions.definition: To pull (something) out; to extract, to remove . To extract (a tooth ); to pull. [from 16th c.] To extract ( juice , oil , or some other fluid ) from something by osmosis , pressure , or another process . [from 16th c.] To extract (a small amount of liquid, especially blood ) by puncturing a surface, or by using a pipette , syringe , or other suction device . To leave ( tea ) temporarily in water to allow the flavour to increase ; to infuse , to steep . [from 18th c.] To pull out (a firearm , sword , or other weapon ) from a holster , sheath , etc.; to unsheathe . [from 12th c.] To take (a beverage) from a cask or keg using a pump or tap ; to tap . To take up (water) from a well or other source , especially by lifting in a container or pumping . [from 13th c.] To soak up (a liquid, etc.); to absorb ; specifically, of an organism (especially a plant ) or one of its parts : to take in ( nutrients , water, etc.). Of a channel , drain , etc.: to carry (water) away. ( historical ) Chiefly in draw and quarter and hang, draw and quarter : to disembowel (someone), especially after hanging as a punishment for high treason . [from 13th c.] ( cooking ) To remove the viscera from (an animal , especially a bird ) before cooking . ( medicine , archaic ) To attract ( humours , pus , etc.), chiefly by bringing to the surface of the body, so it can be dispersed or removed; also, to treat (a wound ) in this way. [from 14th c.] ( mining ) To raise ( coal or ore ) from an underground mine to the surface.
examples: The cat scratched her, drawing blood.
They drew their swords and fought each other.
to draw water from a well using a bucket

subdefinitions.definition: To select (one or more things) at random from a collection of similar things to decide which of a group of people will receive something such as a prize , or undergo something such as an assignment ; also, to select (someone) by this process; to win (a prize) in a lottery or lucky draw .
examples: The winning lottery numbers were drawn every Tuesday.

subdefinitions.definition: To conduct , or select the winning numbers , tickets , etc., for, (a lottery).
To remove the contents of (something, especially a kiln or oven ); to empty .
To fill a bathtub with (water for a bath ); to run (a bath).

To withdraw (something); specifically ( gambling ) , to withdraw (a bet or wager ); also ( horse racing ) , to withdraw (a horse) from a race . [from 17th c.] ( UK , regional , agriculture , horticulture ) Of a plant or its roots : to deplete ( soil ) of nutrients.
To separate ( sheep ) from a flock for a particular purpose , such as breeding or selling .
To be dealt or to take (a playing card ) from the deck ; also, to have (a particular hand) as a result of this.
examples: At the start of their turn, each player must draw a card.

subdefinitions.definition: To fish by dragging a fishing net along (a shore ) or in (a body of water ).
To search (a covert , a wood , etc.) for game or a quarry .

To end (a game or match ) with neither side winning, that is, in a draw . [from 17th c.] ( transitive , cricket ) In a match scheduled to last for a certain period of time : to end (a match) with neither side winning because the team batting last has not completed its innings when the playing time concludes .
examples: I drew my last game against him.

subdefinitions.definition: To separate (a length of lace made by machine ) into sections by removing the threads connecting the sections.
To take milk from (a cow ); to milk .

To separate ( seeds ) from the husks of clover or trefoil ; also, to separate seeds from the husks of (clover or trefoil). ( cricket , rare ) To take (a wicket). ( falconry ) To remove (a hawk ) from a mew after it has moulted . ( thieves' cant ) To steal (something) from a person, especially by picking a pocket ; also to pick the pocket of (someone); to steal from (a place).
To consume ( power ).
examples: The circuit draws three hundred watts.

subdefinitions.definition: To obtain, elicit. To take (something) from a particular source, especially of information; to derive . [from 13th c.] To call forth (something) from a person, to elicit . [from 14th c.] To deduce or infer (a conclusion); to make (a deduction). [from 16th c.] To receive (a salary); to withdraw (money) from a bank etc. [from 16th c.] To elicit information from (someone); to induce (a person) to speak on some subject. (Now frequently in passive.)
examples: He drew comfort from the thought that he was not the first to suffer this way.
She draws her subject matter from the events of her own life.
He tried to draw a conclusion from the facts.
to draw money from a bank
He refused to be drawn on the subject

subdefinitions.definition: To pull out a firearm, sword, or other weapon from a holster, sheath, etc.
To take up water from a well or other source, especially by lifting it in a container or pumping it.
To select one or more things at random from a collection of similar things to decide which of a group of people will receive or undergo something.
To leave tea temporarily in water to allow the flavour to increase; to infuse, to steep; also, of a teapot : to cause tea to infuse.
examples: Tea is much nicer if you let it draw for more than two minutes before pouring.

subdefinitions.definition: Of a bathtub: to be filled with water for a bath; to be run.
Of a channel, drain, etc.: to carry water away.
Of a liquid: to drain away, to percolate .
To treat a wound by attracting humours, pus, etc., chiefly by bringing such material to the surface of the body, so it can be dispersed or removed.
To be dealt or to take a playing card from the deck.
examples: Jill has four diamonds; she’ll try to draw for a flush.

subdefinitions.definition: To take a domino from the stock .
To end a game or match with neither side winning, that is, in a draw; to tie.
examples: We drew the last time we played.

subdefinitions.definition: To take alcoholic beverages from casks or kegs in an inn or tavern ; to work as a drawer or barman . ( falconry ) To remove a hawk from a mew after it has moulted.

definitions.definition: Senses relating to moving or travelling .

subdefinitions.definition: To move in a specific direction.
To move steadily in a particular direction or into a specific position.
examples: The runners drew level with each other as they approached the finish line.
Draw near to the fire and I will tell you a tale.
The end of the world draws near.
Heavy clouds drew together above our heads.
subdefinitions.label_groups: intransitive , used with prepositions and adverbs

subdefinitions.definition: To come to , towards (a particular moment in time); to approach (a time).
examples: As it drew towards evening, I packed up and headed for home.

subdefinitions.definition: To search for game; to track a quarry.

definitions.definition: Senses relating to depicting or representing .

subdefinitions.definition: To produce (a figure , line , picture , representation of something, etc.) with a piece of chalk , a crayon , a pen , a pencil , or other instrument .
examples: He had drawn a mural on the wall of his apartment.

subdefinitions.definition: To carve or shape (something) by cutting off thin pieces.
To make (a comparison or contrast ) between two or more things ; to compare ; to contrast , to distinguish .
Often followed by on or upon and the person or institution providing the money : to write (a bill , cheque , or draft ) to authorize payment of money.
Now chiefly in the form draw up : to compose or write (a piece of text, especially a formal document ).
examples: to draw a memorial, a deed, or bill of exchange

subdefinitions.definition: To depict (something) linguistically ; to portray (something) in words ; to describe .
examples: Her first novel contained a host of characters who were richly and convincingly drawn .

subdefinitions.definition: To create (a furrow ) by pulling a plough through soil.
To arrange or devise (something); to contrive . To produce (a three-dimensional figure of something); to model , to mould , to sculpt .
To produce an image of something with a piece of chalk, a crayon, a pen, a pencil, or other instrument; to make a drawing or drawings.
examples: When I came in she was drawing on a big piece of coloured paper.

main_definition: Senses relating to exerting force or pulling .
secondary_definitions: Senses relating to extending or protracting .
Senses relating to extracting or selecting .
Senses relating to moving or travelling .
Senses relating to depicting or representing .
